metadata.title: Interactive: Visualizing Covid-19 Test Accuracy | by Eli Holder | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: How accurate are the most common Covid-19 tests? What does "accuracy" even mean?

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: I help clients design and develop effective interfaces between busy people and their messy data

all_paragraphs: A while back I was talking with my dad. He heard something wacky about Covid-19 testing accuracy: they were so inaccurate that “you might as well flip a coin.”
That didn’t sound right, but I realized my own understanding of testing accuracy was a bit fuzzy.
So, to clarify, let’s learn about Covid-19 tests, how they’re measured and what that means for detecting infections in a population.
To understand the impact of testing accuracy, we’re going to run some experiments on a small population. Above is 1,000 people.
For the sake of easy numbers, let’s say 2% of our population has Covid-19. This is the disease’s “prevalence.” You can see about 2% of the group above is infected (orange).

(Note: 2% is on the high side. For comparison, North Dakota is the “hotspot du jour” and while we don’t know the state’s actual current prevalence, in the last 10 days there were 5,793 new cases for North Dakota’s 762,062 citizens, or 0.7% of the population).

To understand the accuracy differences between the most common Covid-19 tests, we’re going to simulate how these tests might perform if we tested all 1,000 people in our population. We’ll look at 5 different tests:
Before we get into the tests themselves, let’s understand what “accuracy” means for detecting an infection. There are 2 parts to a test’s accuracy: Sensitivity and Specificity.

To understand these metrics, we’ll divide up our population between people who are actually healthy and people who are actually infected (Note: This is obviously impossible to do in real life, hence the need for tests in the first place).
Above we have all 980 healthy people. Again, black is healthy.
And here we have all 20 infected people. Orange means infected.

Specificity measures how accurately a test diagnoses people who are not infected (i.e. healthy people). To put this another way: Specificity measures how well a test can differentiate “true negatives” from “false positives.”
To understand “specificity”, we only need to look at our healthy people. Below we’ll see how a hypothetical test with 95% specificity would divide up our 980 healthy people.
Given a test that’s 95% specific, 931 (95%) of our 980 healthy people would be correctly diagnosed as negative (above). These are the “true negatives.”
Unfortunately, with a 95% specific test, 49 (5%) of our 980 healthy people would be incorrectly diagnosed as positive. These are the “false positives.”
False positives are bad news because these folks would unnecessarily be isolated and likely take significant healthcare resources away from patients who are actually sick.

Sensitivity measures how accurately a test diagnoses people who are actually infected. To put it another way: Sensitivity measures how well a test can differentiate “true positives” from “false negatives.”
To understand “sensitivity”, we only need to look at our infected people. Below we’ll see how a hypothetical test with 80% sensitivity would divide up our 20 infected people.
Given a test that is 80% sensitive, 16 (80%) of our 20 infected people would be correctly diagnosed as positive (above). These are the “true positives.”
Unfortunately, with an 80% sensitive test, 4 (20%) of our 20 infected people would be incorrectly diagnosed as negative. These are the “false negatives.”
False negatives are trouble because, if someone believes that they’re healthy when they’re actually infected, they may let their guard down and unknowingly infect others around them.
The last consideration is whether the measurement refers to a test’s “analytical” or “clinical” performance.

Clinical performance depends on a number of factors, such as how samples are collected. For example, when PCR tests are based on a Nasopharyngeal Swabs (where they poke your brain with a Q-tip through your nose) they’re less sensitive (73% sensitive), whereas a PCR test based on a sputum sample (coughing up phlegm) is more sensitive (97.2% sensitive)(src).

Below, I’ve tried to report both analytical and clinical measures, where possible. But for the sake of our experiments we’ll use the “analytical” performance, since that measure is more readily available.
When testing an actual sample of 1,000 people, results will vary quite a bit. For example…

Above you can see our 1,000 person population divided by their test results (for our hypothetical test). People who tested negative are in the top group. People who tested positive are in the bottom group.

You’ll notice a few infected (orange) people in the top group. These are the false negatives. This is a result of the test’s imperfect sensitivity. When a test has lower sensitivity, more people who are actually infected will get incorrect negative results.

You’ll also notice that there are some healthy (black) people in the bottom group; these are the false positives and this is a result of the test’s imperfect specificity. When a test has lower specificity, more people who are not infected will get incorrect positive results.
Now that we understand the different metrics of test accuracy (specificity and sensitivity), let’s look at some measurements for real tests and see how they’d perform on our population.
Diagnostic tests tell you whether the disease is present at the time of the test.

PCR tests are the most common type of test. Even though the CDC’s first attempts at these were faulty (src), PCR tests are considered the “gold standard” and the most accurate. The downside: They require trained personnel, expensive equipment and several hours to complete (src).

Rapid antigen tests became available more recently, starting in May. They’re easier to operate on site and can return results in about 15 minutes (src), but they’re generally less accurate. Part of the assumption with these tests is that they can be performed more frequently; even if they’re less sensitive, more frequent tests can be effective over the long run (src).

The FDA approved the Abbot ID NOW test back in March. This is the test they used in the White House (src). (We all know how that worked out.) Like other rapid tests, these work on site and can return results in 5–13 minutes. They’re also supposed to be more accurate than antigen tests, but some studies suggest it’s not as accurate as advertised (src).
Antibody tests determine if the patient was infected at some point in the past.
Blood serum tests detect the disease 1 to 3 weeks after the initial infection (src). They’re generally accurate and you’ll get results back in 3 to 7 days (src).
Obviously flipping a coin isn’t an effective way to detect Covid-19 (Dad!), but let’s see what that looks like:
As expected, you can see that about the same number of people test positive as test negative, and the infected people (orange) are evenly mixed through both groups.
Where did this “coin toss” idea come from? If you google “covid testing coin toss,” you’ll see several credible sources using this analogy.
For example, this Scientific American explainer writes:

“What if there were a nearly perfect test with 99 percent sensitivity and specificity? Seems awesome, doesn’t it? If that test were used in a country with 1 percent prevalence, then the predictive value of a positive test would be only 50 percent — a coin toss!”

“But the accuracy of even these tests depends on the percentage of people in the population who have actually been exposed to the virus. For example, in a population where the prevalence of infection is 5%, a test with 95% specificity and 95% sensitivity will return the same number of false positives as true positives, making any individual result no more useful than the flip of a coin.”

These examples are true, but a bit confusing. It’s important to look at how they’re qualifying the “coin flip” statement. In both of these examples, they’re referring to the test’s Positive Predictive Value, which measures “If I get a positive test result, what’s the probability that I actually have covid?”
This is different from saying “Tests provide no more information than doctors tossing coins in the air,” but it does bring up an important point about how tests are used in practice.

In real life, test results alone aren’t necessarily sufficient to diagnose a person. You also have to consider their context and the person’s prior probability of infection (e.g. Does it seem likely the patient could have been exposed? Did they come in contact with other confirmed patients? Are they symptomatic?).

For example, suppose a positive result with no prior knowledge of the patient’s exposure has a 50% chance of being a true positive, but if you know that person was previously exposed, the positive test result is much more likely to be true. Alternatively, in a population with a low prevalence, if a patient with no prior exposure gets a positive result, you might be a bit more skeptical that it’s a false positive.

This also explains why you might see the CDC change their screening criteria; as Covid’s prevalence rises and falls, so does our prior probability of exposure and testing strategies will change to adapt.
Who am I? No, no, who are you?!

Hi! I’m Eli Holder. I help clients design and develop effective interfaces between busy people and their messy data. If you’re a founder, maker, storyteller, non-profit do-gooder or business leader thinking about the intersection of data, design and user psychology, I’d love to connect and hear your story.
You can email me at eli@3isapattern.com or follow me on Twitter.
Special thank you to Laura Gast for the epidemiology perspective and patient feedback!
